messages.text: So it definitely seems to accept NULLs, so yep, we just need to check this when trynig to follow includes. I always like explicit checks better than catching errors, I think :slightly_smiling_face:

messages.text: <@U6A7NFP62> could you take a look at <https://github.com/julia-vscode/crashreporting-issues/issues/12>? I think we should minimally fix the amount of info we send in the crash reports there, i.e. I think we're sending too much right now.

elements.text: could you take a look at
? I think we should minimally fix the amount of info we send in the crash reports there, i.e. I think we're sending too much right now.

messages.text: I just had a go on the remaining crash reporting issues for LS. I opened PRs for the ones that I understand and can fix, but I think the remaining ones are probably for <@U6A7NFP62>... None of them strike me as particularly difficult, so maybe we should actually try to just fix a bunch more of those before we merge new stuff?

messages.text: I'm starting to wonder whether we should run the tests in all packages that we ship as part of the azure pipeline build, at least on `master`....

elements.text: I'm starting to wonder whether we should run the tests in all packages that we ship as part of the azure pipeline build, at least on
master

messages.text: We're shipping a lot of packages now, and we're updating them without much careful consideration what changed in them... And we don't really know whether they all have CI configured to for example run on all platforms and Julia versions that we want to make sure things work on.

elements.text: We're shipping a lot of packages now, and we're updating them without much careful consideration what changed in them... And we don't really know whether they all have CI configured to for example run on all platforms and Julia versions that we want to make sure things work on.

messages.text: So maybe we should just run all tests in all packages that we ship as part of our CI? Right now we only run the CI in the packages that we develop ourselves...

elements.text: So maybe we should just run all tests in all packages that we ship as part of our CI? Right now we only run the CI in the packages that we develop ourselves...

messages.text: <@U6BNE7LTZ> is <https://github.com/julia-vscode/julia-vscode/blob/master/src/scripts/updateDeps.ts#L31> still the best way to do things? I think you reorganized what the "truth" is for all of this? Or should we just ignore for now because we are going to remove the grammar from our extension in any case as soon as it ships in the VS Code core?

elements.text: is

still the best way to do things? I think you reorganized what the "truth" is for all of this? Or should we just ignore for now because we are going to remove the grammar from our extension in any case as soon as it ships in the VS Code core?

We've got four PRs that I think are very close to merging, maybe we could try to get them all merged today and push out a new insider? Here they are:
• <https://github.com/julia-vscode/LanguageServer.jl/pull/897> (I still have a question about the fallback method there)
• <https://github.com/julia-vscode/SymbolServer.jl/pull/215> (needs review)
• <https://github.com/julia-vscode/LanguageServer.jl/pull/899> (needs review)
• <https://github.com/julia-vscode/LanguageServer.jl/pull/898> (needs review)

messages.text: On the memory issue: does that go up over time? Or is it essentially so large shortly after we start everything? That might allow us to pin down whether the problem is located somewhere in the comm layer, say we don't free memory associated with messages or something like that, vs something that is caused in say the initial analysis stage of a folder.

elements.text: On the memory issue: does that go up over time? Or is it essentially so large shortly after we start everything? That might allow us to pin down whether the problem is located somewhere in the comm layer, say we don't free memory associated with messages or something like that, vs something that is caused in say the initial analysis stage of a folder.

messages.text: Memory usage shoots up when the docs are being added to the server object in `setdocument!`, but interestingly while system memory report shoots up by ~1-2 GB, the `server` object only rises to 120 MB

setdocument!
, but interestingly while system memory report shoots up by ~1-2 GB, the
server
object only rises to 120 MB

messages.text: So I guess something about the `Document` is preventing GC

Document
is preventing GC

messages.text: I noticed that the Documents both are added to the `server` and themselves have a `server` field that is set to the server they’re being added to.. perhaps that circularity is confusing GC somehow

server

field that is set to the server they’re being added to.. perhaps that circularity is confusing GC somehow

messages.text:
I thought about that and whether the way the `URI2` objects are used as keys was creating multiple entries.. but doesn’t seem to be the case
```julia> struct Foo
       x::Int
       end

julia> d = Dict()
Dict{Any, Any}()

julia> f1 = Foo(1)
Foo(1)

julia> d[f1] = 1
1

julia> f1b = Foo(1)
Foo(1)

julia> d[f1b] = 2
2

julia> d
Dict{Any, Any} with 1 entry:
  Foo(1) => 2```

elements.text: I thought about that and whether the way the
URI2
objects are used as keys was creating multiple entries.. but doesn’t seem to be the case

julia> struct Foo
       x::Int
       end

julia> d = Dict()
Dict{Any, Any}()

julia> f1 = Foo(1)
Foo(1)

julia> d[f1] = 1
1

julia> f1b = Foo(1)
Foo(1)

julia> d[f1b] = 2
2

julia> d
Dict{Any, Any} with 1 entry:
  Foo(1) => 2
